questions.text: Which of the following tests is best used to assess the eustachian tube function in patients with intact or perforated tympanic membranes?
questions.solution:
Tympanometry is a test used to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction in patients with an intact or perforated tympanic membrane (TM). It is an objective measure of ET function. Although politzerization can be used, tympanometry is better than politzerization.

Tympanometry allows for the visualization of the changes in the movement of TM in response to variations in external canal pressure. The disadvantage of this method is that middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.

Other tests of ET function include Toynbee’s test, phototubometry, saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears, and sonotubometry.

Politzerization (Option C) is an unsafe and outdated ET function test. It can lead to complications like TM rupture, scarring of ET, epistaxis, and the spread of nasal/pharyngeal infection to the middle ear.

The other listed procedures (Options A and B) are used for ET function testing, but they are done in cases where the tympanic membrane is intact.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with difficulty in hearing. A pure-tone audiogram was obtained, which is shown below. What is the interpretation of this audiogram?
questions.solution:
The given audiogram is suggestive of left-sided mixed hearing loss. 

Interpretation of the audiogram:

  • Blue colour indicates the left ear.
  • > indicates bone conduction (BC), and the threshold is >25 dB. Hence, BC is abnormal, which implies that the abnormality is in the sensorineural pathway.
  • × indicates air conduction (AC), and the threshold is >15 dB. Hence, AC is abnormal.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In addition, the air-bone gap is present, which implies conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, the interpretation is left-mixed hearing loss.

A mixed type of hearing loss presents with defects in both conductive and sensorineural pathways. This type of hearing loss is seen in chronic suppurative otitis media and otosclerosis.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present

Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with presbycusis comes to the clinic for a routine check-up while you are working as an intern in the ENT department. Your professor asks you to perform the Bing test, which you promptly do by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid process and alternatively pressing and releasing the tragus. Which among the following findings do you expect in this patient?

choices.text: Patient says that there is no change in the hearing
Patient hears the sound louder when the ear canal is open
Patient hears the sound louder when the ear canal is occluded
Patient experiences dizziness when the ear canal is occluded

questions.solution:
Among the given options, option C is correct. This patient with presbycusis, which causes sensorineural hearing loss, will hear the sound louder when the ear canal is occluded. 

The test performed here is the Bing test—a test of bone conduction. It is done to evaluate the effect of occlusion of the ear on hearing.

It is performed by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid of the patient. Then, the tragus is pressed inwards and released alternately to occlude and open the external ear canal. The findings will depend on the type of hearing loss.

  • Bing positive - It is seen in patients with normal hearing and those with sensorineural hearing loss. The sound is louder when the ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open. Therefore, in this patient with presbycusis, which causes a sensorineural type of hearing loss, the sound is heard louder when the ear canal is occluded.
  • Bing negative - It is seen in patients with conductive hearing loss. They do not appreciate any change in the loudness.

questions.text: A middle-aged man complained of decreased hearing in his left ear. The following test is done. The man can hear the tuning fork vibrations over his left mastoid but not in front of his left ear. Identify the test performed and the type of hearing loss.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the above image is Rinne’s test. Based on the given scenario, it is found that the patient can hear the tuning fork vibrations over the mastoid but not in front of the ear. Hence, it suggests that bone conduction is greater than air conduction (BC>>AC) which is seen in conductive hearing loss.

There are two major types of hearing loss:

  • Conductive hearing loss - due to impaired sound transmission in the external and middle ears. It affects all sound frequencies. Causes include cerumen/wax plugging of the external auditory canal, otitis externa, otitis media, perforation of the eardrum and otosclerosis. 
  • Sensorineural hearing loss - caused by damage to the neural components of hearing - cochlear hair cells, the cochlear nerve or central auditory pathways. Its causes include aminoglycoside toxicity, prolonged noise exposure, autoimmune disorders, trauma, cerebellopontine angle tumours and stroke. 

These types of hearing losses can be differentiated with the help of tuning fork tests. Eg: Rinne’s, Weber’s and Schwabach’s tests. 

In Rinne’s test, a vibrating tuning fork is first placed on the mastoid bone of the patient. This tests bone conduction (BC). When the patient stops hearing the sound, the vibrating tuning fork is placed in front of the ear. This tests air conduction (AC). In a normal ear, AC is greater than BC, and Rinne’s is said to be positive. 

Weber’s test is performed by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the vertex of the skull. The patient closes their eyes and compares the sound heard in either ear. It tests bone conduction (BC). In a normal patient, the vibrations are heard equally on both sides.

The findings of Rinne’s test and Weber’s test in different types of hearing loss are shown below: 

Schwabach’s test is done to compare the bone conduction (BC) of the patient to a healthy subject.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female patient presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive hearing loss at higher tones. She also classically complains of difficulty in understanding speech and inability to feel her contact lenses. Audiometric tests were done as follows. What is the diagnosis?

Recruitment - absent
Rollover phenomenon - present
Short increment sensitivity index (SISI) - 16%
Stapedial reflex - absent
Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) - Interaural latency of wave V is >0.2ms
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the interpretation of audiometric tests, is suggestive of the diagnosis as Vestibular schwannoma.

Vestibular schwannoma is a benign tumour arising from the vestibular nerve due to the abnormal proliferation of Schwann cells. Bilateral vestibular schwannoma is seen in neurofibromatosis type 2. It is common in both sexes between 40-60 years of age. It usually presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive retro-cochlear sensorineural hearing loss at higher tones with poor speech discrimination. 

Tumour growth presents with corneal and facial hypesthesia (inability to feel the contact lens in the given case) due to the involvement of the trigeminal nerve. Involvement of the facial nerve presents as hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall, known as the Hitzelbergers sign and defective taste and lacrimation. Involvement of lower cranial nerves presents as dysphagia, aspiration, voice change, and regurgitation. Rarely cerebellar symptoms may also be seen.

  • Pure tone audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in high frequencies.
  • Speech audiometry shows the roll-over phenomenon.
  • The absence of the recruitment phenomenon is noted.
  • Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) ranges from 0-20%.
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) demonstrates a significant delay of >0.2 ms in wave V between the two ears.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with gadolinium contrast is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

Surgical removal by X-knife, Gamma knife, or Cyberknife is the treatment of choice. Radiotherapy has no role. 

Other options:

Option A - Presbycusis is the physiological hearing loss due to old age and usually manifests at 65 years of age. Presbycusis occurs due to sensory, neural, metabolic, and conductive pathologies and presents predominantly cochlear hearing loss patterns. High-frequency hearing loss with tinnitus are the presenting complaints with positive recruitment phenomenon. Additional features of corneal hypesthesia are absent. 

Option B - Meniere's disease, also known as endolymphatic hydrops, occurs due to overdistension of the inner ear with endolymph. It is more common in males than females. It may be unilateral or bilateral. Cardinal features are:

  • Episodic vertigo
  • Fluctuating hearing loss of cochlear type
  • Tinnitus  
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.

Option C - Noise-induced hearing loss(NIHL) is a preventable cause of hearing loss and is an occupational hazard. NIHL causes damage to outer hair cells more than the inner hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. There is symmetrical hearing loss and shows a cochlear pattern on audiometric tests. The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz, both for air and bone conduction. Speech frequencies are also affected.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the left ear. Rinne’s test shows bone conduction is better than air conduction. Weber test shows lateralization towards the left ear. The absolute bone conduction test is normal. What will be the inference of Schwabach's test in this patient?

choices.text: Lengthened as compared to the examiner
Shortened as compared to the examiner
Same as compared to the examiner
Difficult to interpret with the given data

questions.solution:
The patient here complains of hearing loss. Rinne's test showing BC>AC in the left ear, Weber's test lateralizing to the left ear, and a normal ABC test are suggestive of conductive deafness in his left ear. Schwabach’s test is lengthened in conductive deafness.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration, while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the examiner, but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal: The test result is the same as that of the examiner
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is lengthier than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness: The test result is shorter than that of the examiner

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus(EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive(normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15 - 20 dB.

Weber's test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound is heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worst ear.
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear.

In the absolute bone conduction(ABC) test, the patient’s bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner after occluding (by pressing the tragus inwards) EAC of both the patient and the examiner to prevent the ambient noise from entering through the AC route. It is used to assess cochlear deafness.

  • Normal result: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Sensorineural deafness: The test result is reduced to that of the examiner.

Note: The ABC test and Schwabach's test are done assuming the hearing of the examiner is normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is a subjective test for hearing?
questions.solution:
Speech audiometry is a subjective test for hearing because it requires the patient to actively respond to sound stimuli to assess their hearing.

Other examples of subjective tests are tuning fork tests and pure tone audiometry.

Other options:

Option B: Otoacoustic emission is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

Option C: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Option D: Impedance audiometry is an objective test and consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements. 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing for 2 months. He mentions that he is taking hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He works at a cement manufacturing factory. Otoscopy findings are normal. Rinne’s test result is positive in both ears. Audiometry results are shown below. What is the likely cause of his hearing loss?
questions.solution:
The pure-tone audiogram shown in the given image shows an acoustic dip at 4000 Hz, which is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss. 

The patient's employment history (working at a cement factory) suggests constant exposure to loud noise. Positive Rinne's test result in both ears suggests that air conduction is better than bone conduction, i.e. absence of conductive hearing loss or presence of sensorineural hearing loss.

Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120–155 dB, such as explosions and gunshots, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the organ of Corti. 

The patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in a noisy environment. This condition is irreversible and is managed with hearing aids. 

Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

Other options:

Option A: Medication adverse effects (ototoxicity) cause bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics, loop diuretics (not thiazides), antimalarials, cisplatin, and NSAIDs like ibuprofen, salicylates, and indomethacin.

Option B: Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Pure-tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz, which is known as Carhart's notch. There is a loss of air conduction in the lower frequencies.

The audiogram given below shows Carhart's notch, which is seen in otosclerosis.

Option D: Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph.

World Hearing Day is celebrated on March 3, 2022. Globally, over one billion people are at risk of hearing loss due to loud volumes for long periods. Hearing loss caused by loud sounds is permanent; however, it is also completely preventable. The theme for this year's campaign is "To hear for life, listen with care"

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Schwabach's test?

choices.text: Test is performed with the meatus occluded
Bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of examiner

questions.solution:
Meatus is not occluded while performing the Schwabach test.

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the normal hearing person (examiner), but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal - same as the examiner
  • Conductive deafness - lengthened than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness - shortened than that of the examiner

TUNING FORK TESTS:
I) Rinne’s test:

A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he can still hear it, air conduction is better than bone conduction.

  • Positive - when the air conduction (AC) is longer or louder than bone conduction (BC). Seen in normal persons and persons with sensorineural deafness.
  • Negative - when the bone conduction is better than air conduction. Seen in patients with conductive deafness.

II) Weber test:

A vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard.

  • Normal - heard equally in both ears
  • Conductive deafness - lateralized to the worse ear
  • Sensorineural deafness - lateralized to the better ear.

III) Absolute Bone Conduction test:

Here, the patient’s bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner. The external auditory meatus of both the patient and the examiner should be occluded (by pressing the tragus inwards) to prevent the ambient noise from entering through the AC route.

  • Normal - same as the examiner.
  • Conductive deafness - same as the examiner.
  • Sensorineural deafness - reduced than that of the examiner.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was subjected to a tuning fork test. A vibrating tuning fork was placed on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stopped hearing, it was brought beside his external meatus. The patient could still hear the ringing sound. Repeating the same test in the opposite ear yielded the same result. On placing a vibrating tuning fork on his forehead, it was lateralized to the right ear. What is the likely inference?

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
The given scenario shows a positive Rinne test, indicating air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Since Weber’s test is lateralized to the right ear and Rinne’s test is normal, there is sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear.

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus(EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • It is considered positive (normal) when the AC>BC. This is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC. This is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

In the Weber test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead, or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. Normally, it is heard equally in both ears. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady presents with complaints of ear pain associated with impaired hearing. Further evaluation by otoscopy reveals a dull and lustreless tympanic membrane with prominent lateral process of the malleus. Which of the following curves will be obtained if she undergoes tympanometry?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical case, otoscopy findings of a dull and lustreless tympanic membrane with prominent lateral process of the malleus, are highly suggestive of a retracted tympanic membrane. On Tympanometry, a Type C tympanogram (Curve 1) with normal compliance and negative pressure is seen in the case of a retracted tympanic membrane.

Features of retracted TM:

  • TM is dull and lustreless.
  • The cone of light is absent or interrupted.
  • The handle of the malleus appears foreshortened.
  • The lateral process of the malleus becomes more prominent.
  • Anterior and posterior malleal folds become sickle-shaped.

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube. Results of tympanometry are plotted in the form of a tympanogram with:

  • Compliance on the Y axis (ease of mobility of TM)
  • Middle ear pressure on the X axis (regulated by eustachian tube)

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

Tympanometry has also been used to evaluate the function of the eustachian tube in cases of intact or perforated tympanic membrane. A pressure of —200 or +200 mm H2O is created in the middle ear and the person is asked to swallow 5 times in 20 seconds. The ability to equilibrate the pressure indicates normal tubal function. It is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

Curve 2- Type B curve. A flat or dome-shaped graph. No change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane.

Curve 3- Type As curve. Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.

Curve 4- Type Ad curve. High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity or thin and lax tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 13-month-old child presents to you at a local clinic where you are posted for community clinic duty. The parents are apprehensive that their child has difficulty in speech and hearing. Which of the following tests is not useful for assessing the hearing in this child?
questions.solution:
Pure tone audiometry is not useful for assessing the hearing in this child as it cannot be utilised for this age group.

Methods of hearing assessment in infants and children: 

1. Objective tests:

  • Auditory brainstem response

questions.text: In the assessment of a patient with diminished hearing, the function of which of the following structures is tested when the tuning fork is struck and placed on the mastoid?
questions.solution:
When the tuning fork is struck and placed on the mastoid to assess bone conduction, the cochlea is stimulated directly by vibrations conducted through the bones of the skull. Therefore, it is a measure of cochlear function only.

Tuning fork tests are used to assess air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC) in the hearing apparatus. To test AC, the tuning fork is struck and placed in front of the external auditory canal. The sound is conducted through the tympanic membrane, middle ear and ear ossicles to the inner ear. Hence, the conducting mechanism, as well as the cochlea, are assessed. However, to test BC, when the tuning fork is struck and placed on the mastoid or at the vertex, as is done in Weber's Test, the vibrations are conducted through skull bones and not through the ossicles, thereby directly stimulating the cochlea.

Therefore, although it is called the 'bone conduction' test, it is not an assessment of the function of the ossicles but of the cochlea.

For routine clinical practice, a tuning fork of 512 Hz is ideal. The clinically relevant tuning fork tests performed include:

  • Rinne's Test
  • Weber's Test
  • Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test
  • Gelle's Test
  • Schwabach's Test
  • Bing Test

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital complaining of reduced hearing in the right ear. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. All of the following are uses of this instrument except?

choices.text: To determine the degree of hearing loss

questions.solution:
The image is of a digital audiometer (pure tone audiometer). A digital audiometer is a lightweight device that is portable and can be used to perform hearing tests, including pure tone audiometry. This device does not measure acoustic reflexes. 

Acoustic reflex is measured using the impedance audiometer.

An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram.

The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.

Uses of pure tone audiometer:

  • To measure the threshold of hearing of air and bone conduction
  • Helps to predict speech reception threshold (SRT)
  • To diagnose the type and degree of hearing loss.
  • For the prescription of hearing aids
  • Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes
  • A record can be kept for future reference.

Impedance audiometry includes tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurement, which are objective tests of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing).

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present

Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: Which among the following tests is not used for neonatal screening of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, distraction techniques are not used for neonatal screening of hearing loss. 

Distraction techniques are used in children of age 6-7 months. High-frequency sounds, low-frequency sounds, whispered sounds and warbled tones are used to distract the child. The child responds by turning the head toward the source of sound if the hearing is intact.

Other options: 

Option B: Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea. It is an objective test of hearing. They can be used as screening tests for hearing in neonates. It can be used to diagnose neuropathy of the 8th cranial nerve. OAEs are absent in conditions like middle ear effusion and non-functional outer hair cells in the cochlea.

Option C: Arousal test is used for screening neonatal hearing. Here, when the infant is in light sleep, high-frequency narrow-band noise is presented for 2 seconds. An infant with normal hearing is aroused from sleep twice when three such stimuli are given.   

Option D: Auditory response cradle test is used for screening neonatal hearing. In this, the behaviour of the baby lying in the cradle is monitored using transducers in response to auditory stimuli. It can identify infants with moderate, severe, or profound hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: In the given image, Graph A shows the electrocochleogram of a normal ear and Graph B of a diseased ear. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis indicated by Graph B?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis indicated by Graph B is Meniere’s disease.

Normally, the ratio of summating potential (SP) to action potential (AP) is 30%. In Méniére’s disease, the SP/AP ratio is greater than 30% which is diagnostic.

Electrocochleography (EcoG):

  • It is an objective test that records the electrical activity of the cochlea and 8th nerve in response to auditory stimuli
  • Techniques employed: Transtympanic(invasive) and Extratympanic(non-invasive)
  • The response is in the form of three phenomena as follows,
    - Cochlear microphonics: measures the electrical activity that follows the stimulus and reflects the instantaneous displacement of the basilar membrane.
    - Summating potential: measures the electrical activity of the hair cells within the organ of Corti.
    - Action potential: electrical activity in the distal part of the auditory nerve.

questions.text: A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the changes in air pressure in the ear canal are brought about by Siegel’s speculum. This test is positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected. What is the test discussed here?
questions.solution:
The test discussed here is Gelle's test.

It is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of increased air pressure in the ear canal on hearing. Normally, when air pressure is increased in the ear canal by Siegel’s speculum, it pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards, raises the intralabyrinthine pressure, and causes immobility of the basilar membrane and decreased hearing.

When the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected, there will be no change in hearing. It was a popular test to find out stapes fixation in otosclerosis but has now been superseded by tympanometry.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with right-sided sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. On examining his ear, you notice numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal. Which of the following speech audiometric graphs represents this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, symptoms of unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus and numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal (Hitzelberger sign) are highly suggestive of Acoustic Neuroma which shows the characteristic roll-over phenomenon (Graph D), in speech audiometry.

In speech audiometry, the patient’s ability to hear and understand speech is measured. Speech reception threshold and discrimination score/score percentage are studied under this test. The speech reception threshold is the lowest intensity of sound at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient, and the discrimination score is the percentage of test words correctly repeated by the patient and is calculated as follows:

If a 50-word list is used, 2% is given for each correct response, and if a 25-word list is used, 4% is given for each correct response.

The Roll-over phenomenon is seen on plotting the discrimination score against the amplitude of the sound. It is a feature of retro-cochlear/neural lesions wherein the speech discrimination steadily increases with intensity but suddenly drops significantly beyond a particular intensity of sound due to nerve fatigue.

Acoustic neuroma is also called vestibular schwannoma or neurilemmoma, or eighth nerve tumor. It arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve. It is the most common cerebellopontine angle tumor and is associated with neurofibromatosis 2. It is common in both sexes between 40-60 years of age. 

Clinically, patients typically present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus. Involvement of other cranial nerves results in the following symptoms:

  • Trigeminal nerve: reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of the face.
  • Facial nerve: hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall called Hitzelberger’s sign.
  • Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve: Dysphagia and hoarseness.

Central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei, termed Verocay bodies are found in schwannomas. 

MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for diagnosis. It shows an ice cream cone appearance.

The treatment of choice is the surgical removal of the tumor. Stereotactic radiosurgery, like X-knife or gamma knife surgery, is used for people who refuse/ cannot tolerate surgery.

Other options:

Graph A- seen in a patient with normal hearing.

Graph B- seen in conductive deafness.

Graph C- seen in cochlear disorders like Meniere's disease, will rather show a plateau after a certain level, unlike the fall seen in the roll-over phenomenon. 

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is being evaluated for sensorineural hearing loss after an episode of meningitis. The patient is screened for the threshold of hearing using a test that comprises the following waveforms. Which waveform represents the lateral lemniscus?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the waveforms seen in brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA), and wave V represents the lateral lemniscus.

Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. Stimuli are applied in the form of clicks or tone bursts, which then elicit brainstem responses. Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10 minutes. 

  • Wave I by the distal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave II by the proximal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave III by the cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV by superior olivary complex
  • Wave V by lateral lemniscus
  • Waves VI and VII by the inferior colliculus

The first, third, and fifth waves are the most stable and are used in measurements.

Uses of BERA are:

  • As a screening procedure for infants.
  • To determine the threshold of hearing in infants also in children, and adults who do not cooperate and are malingerers.
  • To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g. multiple sclerosis or pontine tumors.
  • To monitor VIII cranial nerve intraoperatively in surgery of acoustic neuroma to preserve the function of the cochlear nerve.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text:
A woman who came to the ENT Outpatient department was tested with the instrument given below for impaired hearing. Which of the following tests can be performed with this instrument?
  1. Weber’s test
  2. Schwabach’s test
  3. Threshold Tone Decay Test
  4. Gelle’s test
  5. Short Increment Sensitivity Index
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is a tuning fork. Weber’s test, Schwabach’s test, and Gelle’s test can be done with a tuning fork.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration, while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Weber’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is better heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • It is reported as normal when the sound is heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralised to the worst ear.
  • In sensorineural deafness it is lateralized to the better ear.

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the examiner, but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal: The test result is the same as that of the examiner
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is lengthier than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness: The Test result is shorter than that of the examiner

Gelle’s test is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of increased air pressure in the ear canal on hearing. Normally, when air pressure is increased in the ear canal by Siegel’s speculum, it pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards. This raises the intralabyrinthine pressure and causes immobility of the basilar membrane and decreased hearing. But, no change in hearing is observed when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected. Gelle’s test is positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss.

The threshold tone decay test is a measure of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute, but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. A decay of more than 25 dB is diagnostic of a retrocochlear lesion.

The Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI )test distinguishes between a cochlear and a retrocochlear lesion. Patients with cochlear lesions distinguish smaller changes in the intensity of pure tone better. In this test, a continuous tone is presented 20 dB above the threshold and sustained for about 2 min. Every 5 seconds, the tone is increased by 1 dB and 20 such blips are presented. The patient indicates the blips heard. In conductive deafness, the SISI score is seldom more than 15%. It is 70%-100% in cochlear deafness and 0%-20% in retrocochlear (nerve) deafness.
